title: Question 222

children: A 78-year-old man is evaluated for progressive weakness, fatigue, and myalgia over the past 6 months. He lives alone in his home after the death of his partner 4 years ago. Physical examination is noncontributory.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next test?

Vitamin D deficiency may result in osteomalacia, which is characterized by diffuse bone pain, bone tenderness to palpation, and proximal muscle weakness; however, early osteomalacia may present only with low bone mass on dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry and may be indistinguishable from osteoporosis without further testing.
Vitamin D deficiency is characterized by mild hypocalcemia, mild hypophosphatemia, increased alkaline phosphatase and parathyroid hormone levels, and a decreased serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D level.
The most appropriate next diagnostic test is to measure this patient's serum level of 25-hydroxyvitamin D [25(OH)D] (

). He likely has vitamin D deficiency, which is characterized by mild hypocalcemia, mild hypophosphatemia, increased alkaline phosphatase and parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels, and a decreased serum 25(OH)D level. Vitamin D deficiency may result in osteomalacia, which is characterized by diffuse bone pain, bone tenderness to palpation, and proximal muscle weakness; however, early osteomalacia may present only with low bone mass on dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) and may be indistinguishable from osteoporosis without further testing. In the evaluation of vitamin D deficiency, measurement of 25(OH)D (calcidiol) is more informative than measurement of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D [1,25(OH)2 D] (calcitriol) (

) in most patients with hypocalcemia because vitamin D deficiency causes hypocalcemia and stimulates PTH secretion, which in turn stimulates renal conversion of 25(OH)D to 1,25(OH)2 D. Low dietary intake, poor absorption of vitamin D, and lack of production in the skin will result in a low serum 25(OH)D level. This serum level will also be low in patients taking phenytoin, those with nephrotic syndrome (loss of vitamin D–binding protein), and those with hepatobiliary disease. Whereas 25(OH)D has a long half-life, 1,25(OH)2 D is more short-lived and therefore not a good measure of vitamin D status. 1,25(OH)2 D levels will be low despite normal or high 25(OH)D levels in patients with renal insufficiency, deficiency of renal 1α-hydroxylase (vitamin D–dependent rickets, type 1), or hypoparathyroidism.

) is not the most appropriate next test. The results of DEXA scanning are likely to show low bone mineral density, and if the patient has confirmed vitamin D deficiency, he will receive supplemental vitamin D and calcium regardless of the DEXA scan result. Furthermore, DEXA scan cannot differentiate between osteoporosis and vitamin D deficiency as a cause of low bone mineral density.

The most commonly reported radiographic findings of osteomalacia due to vitamin D deficiency are reduced bone mineral density and thinning of the cortex; these findings are nonspecific and not diagnostic. Radiographic changes in vertebral bodies and the presence of Looser zones (narrow radiolucent lines) in the femoral neck or shaft are more diagnostically specific. However, measurement of 25(OH)D is the most direct method to diagnose vitamin D deficiency and is preferred to radiographic surveys (
) in the diagnosis of vitamin D deficiency.

references: Bouillon R, Carmeliet G. Vitamin D insufficiency: definition, diagnosis and management. Best Pract Res Clin Endocrinol Metab. 2018;32:669-84.
